pr_title: Fix partitioned spatial joins with small spatial index

timeline.bodyText: The implementation doesn't actually allow this yet
timeline.author: aweisberg
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -456,6 +460,41 @@ else if (alignment < 0) {
                 kdbTree.map(KdbTreeUtils::toJson)));
     }
 
+    private static boolean isSphericalJoin(Metadata metadata, RowExpression firstArgument, RowExpression secondArgument)
+    {
+        Type sphericalGeographyType = metadata.getType(SPHERICAL_GEOGRAPHY_TYPE_SIGNATURE);
+        return firstArgument.getType().equals(sphericalGeographyType) || secondArgument.getType().equals(sphericalGeographyType);
+    }
+
+    private static boolean canPartitionSpatialJoin(JoinNode joinNode)
+    {
+        /*
+         * A fundamental limitation in distributing joins (broadcast or partitioned)
+         * is when a side is an outer join, and a row in that side is on more than one worker.
+         * This is because you cannot determine if that row has no matches given the
+         * local information (another worker may have found a match), so the worker
+         * doesn't know whether to emit a NULL for the non-match.
+         *
+         * This can happen if:
+         * 1. A side is broadcast, and it's OUTER on that side (including FULL).
+         * 2. A side is partitioned, the object is extended (ie, not a Point),
+         *    and it's OUTER on that side (including FULL).
+         *
+         * We assume that the right node is the build side.  The CBO is disabled
+         * for spatial joins, so this should be a good assumption.  Then we have:
+         * 1. INNER joins are OK.
+         * 2. LEFT joins when the left node is a Point are OK.

timeline.author: aweisberg

timeline.message:
Assign partition index to geometries outside of KdbTree

Currently, if a geometry is outside the bounding box of a KdbTree, it is
dropped: it's assigned an empty partition index array, which is
unnested, resulting in the row being dropped.  This can be an efficiency
measure: if one side of the join is much smaller than the other, then
the bounds will drop many rows before they are sent to the join worker.

However, if the bounds are less than both the build- and probe-side of
the join, then rows that would have matched in a non-partitioned join
will be dropped when you partition the join.  This makes the correctness
of the partitioned join dependent on the partition chosen, which can
lead to some surprising output changes that could be reasonably viewed
as data loss.

This change adds a special partition index (-1) to any geometry that
intersects the outside of the KdbTree: in effect, making one additional
"outside" partition.  This trades a potential correctness issue for one
of skew, that in the worst case will fail the query.  The user can then
make a more appropriate spatial partitioning.

Assign partition index to geometries outside of KdbTree

Currently, if a geometry is outside the bounding box of a KdbTree, it is
dropped: it's assigned an empty partition index array, which is
unnested, resulting in the row being dropped.  This can be an efficiency
measure: if one side of the join is much smaller than the other, then
the bounds will drop many rows before they are sent to the join worker.

However, if the bounds are less than both the build- and probe-side of
the join, then rows that would have matched in a non-partitioned join
will be dropped when you partition the join.  This makes the correctness
of the partitioned join dependent on the partition chosen, which can
lead to some surprising output changes that could be reasonably viewed
as data loss.

This commit changes the bounding box of the KdbTree to extend from
-Infinity to +Infinity, so that all (non-empty) geometries will get
at least one partition.

Additionally, make the internal intersection/containement checks for
each KdbTree node use strict equality for upper/right borders, which
makes points intersect only one node.

However, if the bounds are less than both the build- and probe-side of

will be dropped when you partition the join.  This makes the correctness
of the partitioned join dependent on the partition chosen, which can
lead to some surprising output changes that could be reasonably viewed
as data loss.

at least one partition.

Additionally, make the internal intersection/containement checks for

will be dropped when you partition the join.  This makes the correctness
of the partitioned join dependent on the partition chosen, which can

This commit changes the bounding box of the KdbTree to extend from

at least one partition.

Additionally, make the internal intersection/containement checks for
each KdbTree node use strict equality for upper/right borders, which
makes points intersect only one node.

Improve spatial join tests

This commit adds more data to the spatial join tests, to test cases
where geometries may be outside the range of those geometries used
to build the spatial index.

to build the spatial index.
